sections.text:
This feature adds a durable link between the positioning recommendation a customer used and the results it drove. Today, when a recommendation is applied—exported to sales enablement assets, pushed into a segment brief, or embedded in email/landing-page templates—we lose the ability to reliably attribute downstream outcomes to the exact positioning version that was active at creation time.

By persisting `positioning_version_id` on all customer-facing artifacts at generation/apply time, and on any subsequent tracked outcome events (e.g., conversion, win/loss, churn), we create a consistent join key back to the existing positioning change log. This enables precise “which positioning performed best” analysis, supports audits/debugging when results change over time, and avoids ambiguity caused by later edits or new versions.

The impact for customers is clearer measurement and faster iteration: teams can compare outcomes across positioning versions, understand performance shifts after a change, and make evidence-based decisions about what to roll forward or roll back. Internally, it improves data integrity and reduces ad-hoc investigation time when stakeholders ask why a segment’s results changed.

Implementation-wise, this requires minimal schema/index updates to make queries efficient, and careful backfill behavior: historical artifacts/events remain `null` rather than attempting to infer versions, avoiding incorrect attribution. Forward-looking data becomes consistently attributable, unlocking reliable reporting and experimentation without risking retroactive data corruption.
